comments.body:
This may or may not be relevant, but I thought it worth mentioning here just in case:

I've looked into other reports of lag in ASpace and newly-created objects not becoming available in the UI since yesterday. I went in thinking it's an indexing thing, possibly related to bulk updates on Agents I've been running this week. However, I now think this issue is more specific to top_containers.

Here's how I'm arriving at this suspicion:

- Lyrasis checked the ASpace and SOLR servers for us and the logs, and Blake says there's nothing in there to indicate that indexing is or recently was slow. 
- I've followed up on all the reports of disappearing objects in the UI, and the only ones that have stuck (i.e. that I can reproduce, and that I can't exclude as unrelated or mere oversight) are top_containers.
- Staff reports of sluggish performance came in after Lynn had reported the AbID 405

So I think whatever is going on has to do with top_containers. I'll ask Blake to take a closer look with that angle. If I learn anything more, I'll post it here.

aspace_helpers.title: test new ASpace plugin for component-level aspace2alma

comments.body: It failed yesterday; I suspected that it needed a new data update which I had failed to create. I created a data update to force a fresh export overnight, which it did, but the hand-off to sftp is still failing.

It failed again. This time we were able to narrow it down to a timeout issue.

1. aspace finds sftp, so it's not a Docker issue
2. sftp munges the authentication for a while (not sure why)
3. aspace gets impatient and walks away.

The part where aspace walks away is not aspace proper but a gem that the plugin uses, net-sftp, which looks like it takes a timeout parameter: https://github.com/net-ssh/net-sftp/issues/129. I'll ask James at HM about it.

aspace_helpers.title: Create a monthly job to save a snapshot of our archival description in SVN

comments.body:
Steps:

- [ ] In aspace_helpers on lib-jobs, create a job to download all EADs

       logic)
- [ ] Create a whenever to send EADs to SVN monthly
- [ ] authenticate to SVN
- [ ] send EADs to SVN

orangelight.title: Submit Alma constituent record metadata with Aeon Requests

comments.body:
Looks very promising!
ItemAuthor, ItemTitle, ItemSubTitle, ItemDate, ItemEdition, ItemISxN, ReferenceNumber.
Those are the key "Item ... " fields to map from the constituent.  (All but one.)  ItemVolume, ItemIssue, and ItemPages can be disregarded.  ItemNumber comes from the host.
**In addition**, map constituent 773 $$g to ItemInfo 3.  It's the folder number.  In this way the Alma transactions will be sort of compatible with some of the EAD transactions.  Anyway, folder is key physical identifier.
Fields continuing to come from the host: CallNumber, Location, ItemNumber.

orangelight.title: Changed call number font to Roboto Mono

comments.body:
[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/builds/59444359/badge)](https://coveralls.io/builds/59444359)

Coverage: 95.282%. Remained the same when pulling **9eb2308e69549e87eb7c65523d306269bb875164 on 3275-call-number-font** into **1d1cc41068ad3d8681e560a94fe8dc2e00ed1c8b on main**.

[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/builds/59451884/badge)](https://coveralls.io/builds/59451884)

Coverage: 95.302% (+0.02%) from 95.282% when pulling **a5de043b4ca5ce4b9f82ce74831031dc1194ec5a on 3523_purge_bookmarks_solr** into **1d1cc41068ad3d8681e560a94fe8dc2e00ed1c8b on main**.

> Thanks, @maxkadel ! It's looking good, but I got an error when I ran `bundle exec rake orangelight:clean:bookmarks:without_solr_documents` on staging: > > ``` > RSolr::Error::Http: RSolr::Error::Http - 414 Request-URI Too Long > Error: > 414 Request-URI Too Large > >

414 Request-URI Too Large

>
nginx/1.23.2
> > > ``` Ok, thanks for testing it (I didn't want to without having had another set of eyes on it). It's probably that the default for finding in batches is 1,000, and that's probably too many for building the Solr url. I think we can lower the size of the batches - do you have a guess what size would be reasonable?

Hrm, when I ran it on staging, the number of bookmarks went from 2,193 to 110, which makes me a little nervous - that seems like an awfully big reduction. I wonder if it's not waiting long enough for the Solr response / requesting too often?

> Hrm, when I ran it on staging, the number of bookmarks went from 2,193 to 110, which makes me a little nervous - that seems like an awfully big reduction. I wonder if it's not waiting long enough for the Solr response / requesting too often?

The Solr query was defaulting to only 10 responses, no matter how many ids we requested, so it was calculating way more missing document_ids than were correct. I added a configuration to match the number of bookmarks we look up to the number of rows in the Solr response.

- [x] dpul

- [x] figgy

- [ ] geoserver

All projects listed above now have `vault.yml` files except for geoserver and zookeeper.

Looking at the `group_vars/all/vault.yml` file, there are only 24 variables defined there, they all look shared, and none of them relate to zookeeper or geoserver. On the whole this project is done. If we have specific areas where we need to clean up, we can open new tickets.
